summary:
The Security Council,

Welcoming the report of the Secretary-General on the UN operation in Cyprus, 
Noting the need to extend the UN Peacekeeping Force in Cyprus (UNFICYP) beyond 15 December 2011, 
Echoing the Secretary-General’s belief that the Cypriots themselves are responsible for finding a solution, 
Reaffirming the UN’s primary role in assisting the parties to reach a comprehensive and durable settlement.

Welcoming progress in negotiations, 
Urging leaders to increase momentum, particularly on core issues, 
Reiterating the goal of a bicommunal, bizonal federation with political equality.

Emphasizing the importance of full, flexible and constructive engagement in negotiations, 
Looking forward to decisive progress, 
Welcoming the Secretary-General’s intention to meet with leaders in January 2012.

Noting the need for military confidence-building measures, 
Calling for implementation of remaining measures, 
Urging agreement on further trust-building steps.

Reaffirming the importance of Green Line crossings, 
Encouraging opening of other crossing points.

Convinced of benefits of a comprehensive settlement, 
Urging leaders to foster positive public rhetoric.

Highlighting the international community's supporting role, 
Urging practical steps to help leaders.

Taking note of the stable security situation, 
Urging avoidance of tension-increasing actions.

Recalling the 1989 aide memoire, 
Noting with regret withholding of access to minefields.

Highlighting the Committee on Missing Persons’ activities, 
Urging access to all areas.

Agreeing on the essential role of civil society, 
Welcoming bicommunal contacts and events.

Stressing a rigorous approach to peacekeeping deployments.
Here is a concise summary of the Security Council document:

The Security Council:
